study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a highly water-soluble form of rutin in addressing skin issues caused by prolonged mask-wearing, including inflammation, oxidative stress, hyperpigmentation, and poor wound healing.
results_summary: The study found that soluble rutin significantly reduced oxidative stress, improved wound healing, decreased inflammation, and reduced melanin content in dark skin explants. Clinical results showed reduced skin redness, vascularization, and brown spots, with volunteers reporting improved skin comfort.
population_specificity: Volunteers wearing surgical masks for at least 2 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate rutin's neuroprotective effects on retinal ganglion cells under ischemia-reperfusion conditions, focusing on microglia polarization and JAK/STAT3 signaling.
results_summary: Rutin dose-dependently improved retinal ganglion cell viability, reduced apoptosis, suppressed pro-inflammatory cytokines, promoted M2 microglial polarization, and selectively inhibited JAK1 phosphorylation without affecting STAT3. Molecular docking suggested rutin interacts with JAK1's pseudokinase domain.
population_specificity: Retinal ganglion cells isolated from C57/Bl6 mice, co-cultured with BV2 microglial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rutin could mitigate AFB1-induced neurobehavioral and biochemical abnormalities in rats.
results_summary: Rutin co-administration reduced AFB1-induced depression-like behavior, cognitive impairment, oxidative stress, and inflammation while improving cholinergic, purinergic, and indoleaminergic pathways. It also prevented histological damage in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (six weeks old)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of rutin-Ga(III) complex-mediated antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (aPDT) in reducing Enterococcus faecalis biofilm growth and virulence gene expression.
results_summary: Rutin-Ga(III) complex-mediated aPDT significantly reduced E. faecalis biofilm growth in a dose-dependent manner, increased intracellular reactive oxygen species, and down-regulated virulence genes (ace, gelE, esp). The minimum biofilm eradication concentration was 25 μmol/L, and the light dose was 5 minutes at 300-420 J/cm².
population_specificity: Enterococcus faecalis biofilms (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the modulatory effects of rutin on behavior, myenteric plexuses, and enteric glial cells in a Parkinson's disease animal model.
results_summary: Rutin improved motor capacity and intestinal transit in parkinsonian animals, modulated ileal musculature reactivity through muscarinic activation, and increased colon contractility without affecting cell populations.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats with induced Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of rutin on GBM cell viability, miRNA-125b and STAT3 expression, and its modulation of the inflammatory profile in microglia during indirect interaction with GBM cells.
results_summary: Rutin (30-50 μM) significantly reduced GBM cell viability and expression of miRNA-125b and STAT3, while microglia exposed to rutin-treated GBM conditioned medium showed reduced IL-6, TNF, and STAT3 expression, suggesting anti-tumor effects and modulation of microglia towards an anti-tumor phenotype.
population_specificity: Human GL15-GBM cells and human C20 microglia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how dynamic high-pressure microfluidization (DHPM) affects the physicochemical and thermodynamic properties of soybean protein isolate-rutin (SPI-RT) complexes.
results_summary: DHPM treatment altered SPI structure, enhancing SPI-RT complexation, with optimal results at 120-MPa pressure, leading to improved physicochemical properties, smaller particle size, increased hydrophobicity, and higher phenolic content. Molecular docking confirmed SPI-RT interactions.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic effects and mechanisms of rutin on psoriasis using network pharmacology and experimental validation.
results_summary: Rutin inhibited cell proliferation and reduced inflammatory factors (TNF-α and IL-6) in HaCaT cells and ameliorated psoriasis-like skin lesions in mice by downregulating the AGE-RAGE signaling pathway.
population_specificity: HaCaT cells (in vitro) and BALB/c mice with IMQ-induced psoriasis-like skin inflammation (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how rutin inhibits ferroptosis in pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and the role of PKCα in this process.
results_summary: Rutin was found to protect PAH rats by modifying PKCα structure and activity, thereby suppressing ferroptosis. The study identified PKCα as a key node in rutin's regulation of mitochondrial metabolism related to ferroptosis in PAH.
population_specificity: PAH animal model and pulmonary artery smooth muscle cells (PASMCs) under hypoxia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an efficient, green method for extracting rutin from Sophora japonica and evaluate its potential for pharmaceutical use in cardiovascular and circulatory system diseases.
results_summary: The study found that a green deep eutectic solvent (ChCl-Eth) extracted rutin more efficiently than methanol, yielding 1.34 times higher. Rutin was successfully recovered from the solvent, which could be reused at least 3 times.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects and mechanisms of rutin on cognitive impairment in surgical and aged mice, as well as its impact on LPS-induced BV2 microglial cells.
results_summary: Rutin increased nuclear Nrf2 levels, reduced neural damage, and mitigated caspase-1-mediated pyroptosis and M1 microglia polarization. Its protective effects were mediated via the Nrf2/Mac-1/caspase-1 inflammasome axis.
population_specificity: Aged mice and LPS-induced BV2 microglial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-aging effects of Rutin using Caenorhabditis elegans and a D-Gal-induced aging mouse model, focusing on lifespan, oxidative stress, and behavioral outcomes.
results_summary: Rutin prolonged the lifespan and increased reproductive rate in C. elegans, improved exercise capacity in mice, and significantly reduced oxidative stress markers (ROS, MDA) while enhancing antioxidant enzyme activity (SOD, GSH-Px).
population_specificity: Caenorhabditis elegans and D-Gal-induced aging mice.
effective_dosage: 12.5, 25, and 50 μg/mL for C. elegans; 200 mg/kg for mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rutin protects against kidney damage caused by perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) exposure in mice.
results_summary: Rutin improved glomerular and tubular structural damage, increased serum CREA and HDL-C levels, and decreased LDH and LDL-C levels. It also upregulated AQP1 and ACOT1 expression and affected genes related to lipid metabolism and oxidative stress via PI3K-Akt, PPAR, and NRF2/KEAP1 signaling pathways.
population_specificity: ICR mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rutin alleviates ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI) and to explore its potential therapeutic mechanisms.
results_summary: Rutin reduced lung tissue damage and apoptosis in mice with VILI, suppressed NLRP3 inflammasome activation, and inhibited the TLR4/NF-κB-P65 pathway, promoting M1 to M2 macrophage transition and reducing inflammation.
population_specificity: Mouse model of ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether rutin could mitigate PFOA-induced liver damage in rats by examining its effects on liver enzymes, oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, and inflammatory markers.
results_summary: Rutin co-treatment reduced PFOA-induced liver enzyme elevation, histopathological defects, oxidative damage, and mitochondrial dysfunction. It also lowered the Bax:Bcl2 ratio and suppressed pro-inflammatory gene expression (TNF-α, IL-6, NF-ƙB, JNK), though protection was partial.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidiarrhoeal potential of rutin, a marker compound in Begonia roxburghii, against Shigella flexneri-induced diarrhoea in rats using in vitro, in vivo, and in silico methods.
results_summary: Rutin demonstrated significant antibacterial activity against Shigella flexneri and showed a 75.27% recovery from diarrhoea in rats after five days of treatment. It also reduced stool pathogen density, cytokine expression, and ion loss while enhancing Na+/K+-ATPase activity, supported by molecular docking and network pharmacology.
population_specificity: Rats with Shigella flexneri-induced diarrhoea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate carbopol gel-encased glycerosomes containing Rutin for treating sunburn, focusing on optimizing formulation and assessing therapeutic efficacy.
results_summary: The optimized Rutin-loaded glycerosomes showed sustained drug release, enhanced skin permeation, good antioxidant activity, and better retention in the epidermis, suggesting potential for long-lasting sunburn protection. The formulation was stable, safe, and had good SPF values.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or ex vivo skin models based on characterization methods).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how rutin, induced by ZNC treatment, enhances tomato resistance to Botrytis cinerea infection.
results_summary: The study found that rutin accumulation in tomato plants, triggered by ZNC treatment, improved resistance to B. cinerea by activating ROS generation, MPK phosphorylation, and ET/JA-mediated immune pathways.
population_specificity: Tomato plants (Solanum lycopersicum)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-neuroinflammatory activity of rutin hydrate (RH) in zebrafish models induced by copper sulfate (CuSO4) and lipopolysaccharide (LPS).
results_summary: RH significantly reduced neutrophil mobility and migration in both CuSO4 and LPS models, improved locomotor ability, and modulated gene expression and enzyme activities related to neuroinflammation. Network pharmacology analysis identified key pathways and targets through which RH exerts its effects.
population_specificity: Zebrafish (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physicochemical properties and anticancer effects of mesoporous silica nanoparticles co-loaded with rutin and curcumin (Rut-Cur-MSNs) on head and neck cancer cells (HN5).
results_summary: The study found that Rut-Cur-MSNs exhibited a mesoporous structure, nanometer size, and negative surface charge, with significantly higher cytotoxicity on HN5 cells compared to rutin or curcumin alone. The nanoparticles also induced ROS production in treated cells, suggesting potential anticancer efficacy.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer cells (HN5) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of rutin supplementation on blood pressure, antioxidant enzyme levels, and quality of life in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Rutin consumption significantly reduced blood pressure parameters (SBP, DBP, PP, MAP, HR) and increased antioxidant enzyme levels (SOD, CAT, GPx) as well as improved several quality of life parameters compared to placebo. The changes in emotional limitations, energy, mental health, and general health were also significantly better in the rutin group.
population_specificity: Fifty patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), divided into intervention (n=25) and control (n=25) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rutin supplementation improves pancreatic β-cell function and alters gut microbiota in overweight individuals with normoglycaemia or prediabetes.
results_summary: Rutin supplementation (500 mg/day) did not improve pancreatic β-cell function or significantly alter gut microbiota composition over 12 weeks, though fasting plasma glucose negatively correlated with the abundance of the butyrate producer Roseburia inulinivorans.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 years with BMI of 23-35 kg/m2, either normoglycaemic or prediabetic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rutin seed treatment enhances tomato plant resistance against whitefly (Bemisia tabaci) without negatively affecting plant growth.
results_summary: Rutin seed treatment reduced whitefly nymph development, adult fecundity, and feeding efficiency, while increasing flavonoid accumulation, callose deposition, and JA-dependent defense gene expression without significant shoot growth reduction.
population_specificity: Tomato plants (Solanum lycopersicum)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the anticancer activity and stability of rutin by loading it into PEGylated Nano-phytosomes.
results_summary: The PEGylated Nano-phytosomes loaded with rutin showed improved anticolonic cancer activity (IC50=0.44 μM) compared to pure rutin alone, demonstrating enhanced efficacy and stability.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of rutin alone and in combination with metformin on blood glucose, lipid levels, and vascular function in diabetic rats.
results_summary: Rutin, alone and combined with metformin, significantly improved blood glucose, cholesterol, and triglyceride levels, as well as vascular function, with the combination showing the most pronounced benefits.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic male Sprague Dawley rats
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg body weight/day (rutin), 300 mg/kg body weight/day (metformin)
interactions: Combination with metformin was studied, showing enhanced effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether co-administration of rutin and lithium could improve neurological outcomes and reduce oxidative stress in a rat model of cerebral ischemia-reperfusion injury.
results_summary: Co-treatment with rutin and lithium improved survival, cognitive function, and neurological scores, reduced oxidative stress markers, and modulated gene and protein expressions related to inflammation and neuroprotection.
population_specificity: Middle-aged male rats subjected to transient global cerebral ischemia-reperfusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-colorectal cancer activity of rutin-loaded nanoliposomes against HT-29 human carcinoma cells and characterize their encapsulation efficiency, stability, and drug release properties.
results_summary: Rutin-loaded nanoliposomes demonstrated sustained drug release for 24 hours, improved anti-cancer activity compared to free rutin, and highest encapsulation efficiency at 1.8 mg/ml. PEGylated nanoliposomes showed enhanced selectivity against cancer cells.
population_specificity: Human carcinoma cells (HT-29) in vitro.
study_duration: Stability tested for one month at 4°C; drug release monitored for 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the physicochemical properties and pharmacological pathways of rutin and other flavonoids to understand their protective effects, including anti-inflammatory, cardiovascular, and anticancer benefits.
results_summary: Rutin was predicted to be orally bioavailable, targeting enzymes like kinases and lyases, with key interactions involving TNF, NOS2, and other proteins. It also influenced microRNAs linked to cancer regulation, such as hsa-miR-34a-5p, which controls cell proliferation and apoptosis.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico and molecular analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of rutin-loaded nanofibers (PLArutin) in inhibiting glioblastoma cell viability, migration, and tumor spheroid growth, both alone and in combination with Temozolomide (TMZ).
results_summary: PLArutin caused rapid inhibition of glioblastoma cell viability (p < 0.0001) and effectively suppressed cell migration and tumor spheroid growth. The study found that rutin, when delivered via nanofibers, demonstrated significant anti-cancer effects comparable to other tested compounds (OL and TMZ).
population_specificity: Glioblastoma (GB) cells in vitro (laboratory study, not human subjects).
study_duration: Release characteristics and effects were monitored over 120 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of rutin on metabolic parameters, inflammatory and oxidative stress markers, and brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Rutin supplementation significantly improved metabolic parameters (e.g., reduced FBG, HbA1c, LDL-c, and TG), enhanced insulin sensitivity, increased antioxidant capacity, and reduced inflammatory markers (IL-6, MDA) while elevating BDNF levels compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 50 patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (25 in the rutin group, 25 in the placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Rutin combined with Vitamin C on glycemic control, insulin resistance, lipid profile, and oxidative stress markers in type 2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: Rutin combined with Vitamin C significantly reduced the percentage change in fasting blood glucose compared to controls and improved quality of life domains, but had no effect on HbA1c, total cholesterol, fasting insulin, HOMA-IR, or oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: 53 patients with type 2 diabetes, randomized into three groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) inhibits NSCLC growth, enhances chemosensitivity, and its mechanistic role in autophagy and oxidative stress.
results_summary: SAM inhibited NSCLC growth and enhanced chemosensitivity in vitro and in vivo by targeting the P62/NF-κB axis, blocking autophagy, and activating oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) models (in vitro and in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether an oral supplement containing rutin and forskolin could further reduce intraocular pressure (IOP) in primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) patients already on maximum tolerated medical therapy.
results_summary: The study found that the supplement led to a statistically significant 10% reduction in IOP, with greater effects (15%) in patients with higher baseline IOP. No significant changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: POAG patients under maximum tolerated medical therapy and awaiting filtrating surgery in Italy.
effective_dosage: 2 tablets per day (exact rutin dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) protects against FOLFOX-induced hepatotoxicity and to define the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: SAMe co-treatment completely blocked FOLFOX-induced liver injury, inhibited NF-κB activation, and reduced PAI-1 induction, demonstrating hepatoprotective effects. It also prevented proinflammatory cytokine expression in Kupffer and liver sinusoidal endothelial cells.
population_specificity: Murine models and in vitro studies using primary mouse and human hepatocytes, Kupffer cells, hepatic stellate cells, and liver sinusoidal endothelial cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) secreted by HepLPCs inhibits hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) proliferation by impairing mitochondrial function and suppressing Notch1 and JAK1/STAT3 signaling pathways.
results_summary: The study found that SAM, along with nicotinic acid (NA), secreted by HepLPCs, inhibited HCC growth by inducing mitochondrial dysfunction and co-inhibiting Notch1 and JAK1/STAT3 pathways, suggesting a potential therapeutic role for SAM in HCC treatment.
population_specificity: Human hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cells and liver progenitor-like cells derived from human hepatocytes (HepLPCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a food supplement containing rutin, forskolin, and vitamins B1 and B2 could improve dry eye symptoms and ocular surface health in glaucoma patients with preservative-induced damage.
results_summary: The study found that the supplement significantly increased OPI values and improved dry eye symptoms compared to placebo after 30 days of treatment. The results suggest a protective effect on the ocular surface and restoration of tear film equilibrium.
population_specificity: 38 glaucomatous patients with dry eye induced by long-term use of BAK-preserved eye drops.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the roles of S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) in cancer pathogenesis, its potential as a diagnostic and prognostic marker, and its emerging therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The study found that SAMe plays a multifaceted role in cancer biology, influencing tumor initiation, progression, and therapeutic resistance. It also highlighted SAMe's potential as a biomarker and its therapeutic promise in improving cancer treatment efficacy by restoring methylation patterns and mitigating oxidative damage.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature on cancer biology and therapeutics).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of combining S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) with decitabine on prostate cancer cells, focusing on proliferation, migration, invasion, and methylation changes.
results_summary: SAM reduced prostate cancer cell proliferation, migration, and invasion, and restored decitabine-induced demethylation of proto-oncogenes without re-methylating tumor-suppressor genes. Combination treatment showed additive effects without nullifying each other.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer cells (PC-3) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) in mitigating arsenic-induced nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) by examining its effects on histone modifications and lipid metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that arsenic exposure decreased SAM levels, leading to reduced H3K9me1/2 and increased lipid accumulation. SAM supplementation in vitro restored H3K9me1/2 and attenuated lipid accumulation, suggesting a protective role against arsenic-induced NAFLD.
population_specificity: Rats and HepG2 cells (human liver cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) as an alternative treatment for depression, particularly in individuals with inadequate responses to conventional therapies.
results_summary: The study found that SAMe may be effective in treating depression by modulating neurotransmitter metabolism, reducing neuroinflammation, enhancing neuroplasticity, and regulating gene expression, particularly in treatment-resistant cases. It also suggested potential benefits for other psychiatric and neurological disorders.
population_specificity: Individuals with depression, particularly those resistant to conventional treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy, safety, and optimal dose of S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) in treating liver diseases.
results_summary: SAMe was effective in improving liver-related parameters with minimal adverse events, primarily mild and transient gastrointestinal complaints. The most common doses were 1000 mg or 1200 mg per day, either alone or combined with other treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with liver diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between S-adenosylmethionine synthetase (METK) gene copy number variations and allopurinol resistance in a dog with Leishmania infantum infection.
results_summary: The study found that a decrease in the METK gene copy number was associated with allopurinol resistance in the dog, supporting clinical suspicion of resistance. The dog exhibited relapse of infection despite prolonged allopurinol treatment, along with hematological and biochemical abnormalities.
population_specificity: A two-year-old female spayed Akita Inu dog with Leishmania infantum infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Rutin's potential as a senomorphic agent targeting senescent cells and its ability to alleviate age-related pathologies, including cancer.
results_summary: Rutin demonstrated significant capacity to dampen the pro-inflammatory SASP expression, interfere with key signaling pathways (ATM-HIF1α and ATM-TRAF6), and reduce malignant phenotypes in prostate cancer cells, including chemoresistance. Combining Rutin with chemotherapy improved treatment outcomes compared to chemotherapy alone.
population_specificity: Senescent stromal cells and prostate cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) alters miRNA expression profiles in prostate cancer cells, potentially affecting cancer cell proliferation and migration.
results_summary: AdoMet treatment in PC-3 cells led to differential expression of 17 miRNAs, with bioinformatic analysis showing upregulation of anticancerogenic genes and downregulation of cancer-related pathways. Knocking down hsa-miR-192-5p confirmed reduced cancer cell proliferation.
population_specificity: PC-3 prostate cancer cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between SAM deficiency, histone methylation modification, and neural tube defects (NTDs) in mice, focusing on the role of SAM in cell differentiation and β-catenin signaling.
results_summary: SAM deficiency reduced H3K27me3 modifications, elevated UTX activity, and inhibited β-catenin expression and neural stem cell (NSC) differentiation into neurons and oligodendrocytes. SAM supplementation reduced the incidence of NTDs from 46.2% to 26.2%.
population_specificity: Mice with induced neural tube defects (NTDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy, safety, and optimal dose of S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) for improving mood and behavior-related CNS signs.
results_summary: SAMe was effective in 24 out of 36 studies, with most studies reporting high quality. Adverse events were mild and transient, primarily gastrointestinal disturbances.
population_specificity: Patients with CNS-related signs (mood, behavior, sleep).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) on retinoblastoma cells, including its effects on proliferation, apoptosis, and cell cycle arrest, and to explore its potential mechanisms of action via the Wnt2/β-catenin pathway.
results_summary: SAM arrested the cell cycle of retinoblastoma cells at the G1 phase, induced apoptosis through the Wnt2/β-catenin pathway, and caused morphological and ultrastructural changes. In vitro and in vivo experiments demonstrated SAM's oncogenic effect on retinoblastoma.
population_specificity: Retinoblastoma cell line Y79 and nude mice with subcutaneous tumor formation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) could effectively counter depression-like behaviors in adolescent rats exposed to chronic unpredictable mild stress (CUMS) and explore its impact on gut microbiome interactions.
results_summary: SAMe significantly improved behavioral outcomes, reduced histopathological damage in hippocampal neurons and colon tissues, and modulated the gut microbiota in depressed rats, favorably altering microbial composition and abundance.
population_specificity: Adolescent male Wistar rats subjected to CUMS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antitumor effects of SCR-7952, a novel MAT2A inhibitor, in MTAP-deleted cancers and its potential synergistic interactions with PRMT5 inhibitors.
results_summary: SCR-7952 demonstrated potent and selective antitumor effects in MTAP-deleted cancers, with high binding affinity to MAT2A and minimal impact on metabolic enzymes. Synergistic interactions were observed with SAM-competitive or MTA-cooperative PRMT5 inhibitors, enhancing PRMT5 inhibition and FANCA splicing perturbations.
population_specificity: MTAP-deleted cancers (approximately 15% of all cancers)
interactions: Synergistic interactions with SAM-competitive or MTA-cooperative PRMT5 inhibitors, but not substrate-competitive ones.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the preventive and regressive potential of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) in high fat/high cholesterol (HFHC) diet-induced non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in guinea pigs.
results_summary: SAM treatment reduced HFHC diet-induced increases in serum transaminase activities, hepatic cholesterol, triglycerides, oxidative stress markers, and histopathological scores for steatosis, inflammation, and fibrosis. It also improved prooxidant-antioxidant balance and reduced aortic lesions.
population_specificity: Guinea pigs fed a high fat/high cholesterol diet to induce NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) could inhibit glioblastoma (GBM) cell viability, proliferation, and DNA repair mechanisms while inducing cell cycle arrest, apoptosis, and mitotic catastrophe.
results_summary: AdoMet selectively inhibited GBM cell viability and proliferation, induced cell cycle arrest and apoptosis, downregulated DNA repair proteins, and promoted mitotic catastrophe. It also maintained DNA damage and inhibited Aurora B kinase, leading to cell death in patient-derived GBM cells.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma (GBM) cell lines (U87MG, U343MG, U251MG) and patient-derived GBM cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of (S)-S-adenosylmethionine in alleviating symptoms of pre-menstrual disorders through an open-label pilot study.
results_summary: The study proposed a protocol to evaluate symptom changes across four menstrual cycles, with two cycles involving oral (S)-S-adenosylmethionine treatment. Results were not yet available, but the study aimed to provide preliminary data for future larger trials.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-45 experiencing pre-menstrual disorders.
effective_dosage: 400 mg three times daily (total 1200 mg/day) during the pre-menstrual phase (14 days prior to menses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) negatively regulates MCJ expression in the liver and its role in mitigating mitochondrial dysfunction in liver diseases.
results_summary: The study found that SAMe reduces hepatic MCJ expression, which is upregulated in liver diseases. MCJ silencing protected against alcohol-induced mitochondrial dysfunction and lipid accumulation, suggesting SAMe's potential therapeutic role.
population_specificity: Liver disease models, specifically focusing on alcohol-associated liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of SAMe as a monotherapy or adjunctive therapy for major depressive disorder (MDD) compared to placebo or other antidepressants.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in depression relief between SAMe and placebo or active agents (imipramine or escitalopram) as monotherapy or adjunctive therapy. Results should be interpreted cautiously due to limited studies and variable SAMe dosages.
population_specificity: Patients with major depressive disorder (MDD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential protective role of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) in aortic dissection (AD) by examining its effects on autophagy inhibition, cellular phenotypic switch, and the PI3K/AKT/mTOR signaling pathway.
results_summary: SAM significantly reduced AD incidence, prolonged survival, and minimized vascular elastic fiber disruption in AngII-induced mice. It also inhibited autophagy and cellular phenotypic switch by modulating contractile and synthetic marker proteins, primarily through activation of the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway.
population_specificity: ApoE-/- mice and primary vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) induced by AngII.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) alters histone methylation marks (H3K4me3 and H3K27me3) in prostate cancer cells and how these changes relate to anticancer effects.
results_summary: SAM treatment altered methylation profiles of H3K4me3 and H3K27me3, leading to upregulation of anticancer-related genes and downregulation of oncogenes, supporting its potential as an anticancer agent.
population_specificity: PC-3 prostate cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) could protect against irinotecan-induced intestinal barrier dysfunction and microbial dysregulation in mice and human Caco-2 cells.
results_summary: SAM pretreatment reduced body weight loss and diarrhea in mice, improved intestinal permeability, and restored tight junction protein expression. In Caco-2 cells, SAM reduced ROS, protected barrier function, and inhibited the p38 MAPK/p65 NF-κB/MLCK/MLC pathway.
population_specificity: Mice and human colon cell line Caco-2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perinatal SAM supplementation could protect against AD-like symptom manifestation in TgCRND8 mice by influencing PSEN1 methylation and amyloid deposition.
results_summary: Perinatal SAM supplementation was as effective as post-weaning treatment in reducing PSEN1 expression and amyloid plaque formation in adult mice, highlighting the role of early-life methyl donor availability in healthy aging.
population_specificity: Transgenic TgCRND8 mice (a model for Alzheimer's disease).
study_duration: Perinatal (from mating to weaning) vs. post-weaning periods

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAMet) could mitigate bacterial translocation, proinflammatory cytokines, oxidative stress, and apoptosis markers in rats subjected to hepatic ischemia/reperfusion injury (IRI).
results_summary: SAMet treatment significantly prevented increases in endotoxin, lipid peroxidation, proinflammatory cytokines, and apoptotic markers while restoring GSH, ATP, and IL-10 levels, improving survival rates in rats with hepatic IRI.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats subjected to hepatic ischemia/reperfusion injury.
study_duration: Single dose before ischemia, with effects measured after 10 and 120 minutes of reperfusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) supplementation could reverse arsenic-induced bile acid accumulation and liver injury by restoring H3K36me3-dependent transcription of Fxr and Fgfr4.
results_summary: SAM supplementation reversed arsenic-induced bile acid accumulation and liver injury by reactivating H3K36me3-dependent transcription of Fxr and Fgfr4, demonstrating its efficacy in mitigating epigenetic and metabolic disruptions caused by arsenic exposure.
population_specificity: Rat model of arsenic-induced liver injury

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of MAT2A (the primary producer of S-adenosylmethionine) in multiple myeloma and explore its potential as a therapeutic target to overcome drug resistance.
results_summary: MAT2A inhibition reduced intracellular SAM levels, impaired myeloma cell viability and proliferation, induced apoptosis, and inactivated the mTOR-4EBP1 pathway. The MAT2A inhibitor FIDAS-5 significantly reduced tumor burden in vivo and synergistically enhanced the anti-myeloma effect of bortezomib.
population_specificity: Multiple myeloma patients and primary human CD138+ myeloma cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) acts as a bridge between the gluconeogenic enzyme PCK1 and H3K9 trimethylation in suppressing hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) progression.
results_summary: The study found that SAM, generated via the serine synthesis pathway, supported H3K9me3 modification, which suppressed the oncogene S100A11. SAM supplementation or S100A11 knockout attenuated HCC progression driven by PCK1 deficiency in vivo and in vitro.
population_specificity: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) models (in vivo and in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the correlation between S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) supplementation and improved cognitive function through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant overall improvement in cognition from SAM supplementation in humans or animals, though subgroup analyses indicated potential benefits in younger animals (≤8 weeks) and with longer intervention durations (>8 weeks). The Morris water maze test suggested SAM might enhance spatial learning and memory in animals.
population_specificity: Humans and animals (specific species not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: Varied, with subgroup analysis noting significant effects for interventions >8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanism by which S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) provides neuroprotection against perioperative neurocognitive disorder (PND) by analyzing chromatin accessibility and gene expression changes.
results_summary: The study identified key genes and pathways, particularly Wnt signaling, inflammatory response, transcription, and long-term potentiation, as mediators of SAM's neuroprotective effects. ATAC-seq and RNA-seq data highlighted chromatin accessibility changes and implicated specific transcription factors in SAM's action against PND.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro models based on methodology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) on melanoma cell behavior and its potential as a combination therapy with immune checkpoint inhibitors (CPI).
results_summary: SAM promoted melanoma cell differentiation, reduced tumor growth and metastasis, and enhanced anti-cancer efficacy when combined with anti-PD-1 antibody, including increased immune cell infiltration and CD8+ T cell function.
population_specificity: Syngeneic BRAF mutant and wild-type melanoma mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of SAM on D-galactose-induced brain aging and explore its underlying mechanisms, focusing on cognitive function and depression-like behaviors.
results_summary: SAM reversed cognitive impairment and depression-like behaviors, reduced neuronal cell loss, increased brain-derived neurotrophic factor, inhibited amyloid-β and microglia activation, and enhanced antioxidant capacity in the hippocampus.
population_specificity: Rats with D-galactose-induced brain aging

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) alone or in combination with an anti-PD-1 antibody could reduce tumor growth and metastasis in luminal B breast cancer.
results_summary: SAM alone reduced tumor growth and metastasis in luminal B breast cancer models, but the combination of SAM and anti-PD-1 antibody showed the highest anti-cancer efficacy, reducing metastasis and enhancing immune response. Transcriptome analysis revealed downregulation of pro-metastatic genes and upregulation of immunostimulatory pathways.
population_specificity: Syngeneic mouse model of luminal B breast cancer (Eo771, R221A cell lines).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) could protect against acetaminophen (APAP)-induced hepatotoxicity by upregulating antioxidant genes and maintaining glutathione (GSH) levels in mouse hepatocytes.
results_summary: SAMe pretreatment increased the expression of APAP metabolism-related and antioxidant genes (Cyp2e1 and Ugt1a1), elevated intracellular GSH concentration, and maintained GSH levels after APAP treatment, demonstrating a protective effect against hepatotoxicity.
population_specificity: Normal mouse AML12 hepatocytes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate an LC-MS/MS method for measuring SAM and SAH in plasma, urine, and cells, and to assess their concentrations in healthy individuals and patients with inborn errors of methyl group metabolism.
results_summary: The study successfully developed an optimized LC-MS/MS method for SAM and SAH measurement, detecting abnormal concentrations in patients with metabolic errors and preserved variations in healthy adults after dietary interventions.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals (19-60 years old) and patients with inborn errors of methyl group metabolism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) on cell cycle, apoptosis, and cancer-related pathways in prostate cancer cell lines.
results_summary: SAM treatment induced S-phase cell-cycle arrest, downregulated cyclin A, upregulated p21, increased the Bax/Bcl-2 ratio and caspase-3 activity, and elevated apoptosis rates. It also downregulated Erk1/2 and STAT3 phosphorylation and reduced STAT3 protein expression.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer cell lines (PC-3 and DU145).
study_duration: Time-dependent effects observed, but exact duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how metformin-induced reduction of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) levels in adults influences lifespan and healthspan through histone methylation pathways.
results_summary: The study found that metformin reduces SAM levels in adults but not larvae, linking this reduction to lifespan extension via H3K4 methyltransferase/demethylase activity, which downregulates targets like mTOR and S6 kinase.
population_specificity: Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) could improve sleep quality and cognitive performance in individuals with Down syndrome (DS) and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).
results_summary: The study observed a significant improvement in the apnea/hypopnea index (AHI) from 51.2 to 17.2 over 49 months in an adult male with DS treated with SAMe and CPAP, suggesting potential benefits of SAMe for OSA in this population.
population_specificity: Adult male with Down syndrome and obstructive sleep apnea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) on liver diseases, viral hepatitis, and various cancers, as well as its potential to enhance other treatments.
results_summary: SAM showed positive effects in animal models for liver diseases and cancer, but human trials yielded modest results. It enhanced antiviral effects in vitro and improved early viral kinetics in hepatitis patients. SAM also demonstrated antitumor effects in various cancer cell lines and improved genomic stability.
population_specificity: Animal models, human patients with NAFLD, viral hepatitis, and various cancer cell lines.
interactions: PegIFN-alpha-2a/2b, ribavirin, betaine, Decitabine, doxorubicin, gemcitabine

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antiviral activity of DZNep, an inhibitor of S-adenosylmethionine-dependent methyltransferase, against SARS-CoV-2 and its role in regulating viral RNA methylation and protein synthesis.
results_summary: DZNep inhibited SARS-CoV-2 RNA and protein synthesis by disrupting m6A methylation and hnRNPA1 recruitment, leading to defective viral RNA capping and reduced viral replication. No DZNep-resistant mutants were observed after long-term viral passage.
population_specificity: In vitro study using SARS-CoV-2 and infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) in infected cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine analog sinefungin could inhibit TGS1 activity, increase hTR levels, and promote telomere lengthening in various cell types.
results_summary: The study found that sinefungin treatment inhibited TGS1 activity, increased hTR levels, and led to telomere lengthening in different cell types, suggesting potential for restoring telomere length in TBD patients with reduced hTR.
population_specificity: Various cell types (specific human populations not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant potential and safety of GR15, a peptide derived from S-adenosylmethionine synthase, in reducing oxidative stress.
results_summary: The study found that GR15 exhibited dose-dependent antioxidant activity, reduced ROS levels in vitro and in vivo, and showed no toxicity in MDCK cells and zebrafish embryos. It also upregulated antioxidant genes, enhancing cellular defense against oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Arthrospira platensis (spirulina or cyanobacteria), MDCK cells, and zebrafish embryos.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method for accurately measuring SAM and SAH concentrations and to study their metabolic transformations in cells and tissues.
results_summary: The study developed a highly sensitive method for detecting SAM and SAH, demonstrated its application in tracking isotopic labeling in cells, and revealed distinct effects of selenium compounds on SAM levels in cancer cells.
population_specificity: Mouse livers and lung adenocarcinoma cells (A549 and H1299).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) supplementation could improve fatigue scores in colorectal cancer patients undergoing oxaliplatin-based chemotherapy.
results_summary: Patients receiving SAM supplementation showed significantly higher FACIT-F scores (indicating reduced fatigue) at 3 and 6 months compared to those without supplementation, with differences in physical, emotional, and total fatigue domains.
population_specificity: 145 colorectal cancer patients (91 adjuvant, 54 metastatic, including 40 with liver metastases) treated with oxaliplatin-based regimens.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how dietary vitamin B12, acting through the methionine/S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) cycle, impacts Aβ proteotoxicity in Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Vitamin B12 alleviated mitochondrial fragmentation, bioenergetic defects, and oxidative stress, delaying Aβ-induced paralysis without affecting Aβ accumulation. The protective effect was mediated by its role as a cofactor for methionine synthase in the SAMe cycle.
population_specificity: Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans) models of Alzheimer's disease with Aβ proteotoxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) could enhance the antitumor activity of 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) in colorectal cancer cells by overcoming chemoresistance mechanisms.
results_summary: AdoMet enhanced 5-FU's antitumor effects by inhibiting autophagy, reducing P-glycoprotein expression, and decreasing acetylated NF-κB levels, thereby overcoming chemoresistance in colorectal cancer cells.
population_specificity: HCT 116p53+/+ and LoVo colorectal cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe)-dependent changes in phosphorylation contribute to liver pathology, particularly in the progression from NASH to HCC.
results_summary: The study found that SAMe-sensitive phosphorylation of LARP1-T449 by CDK2 enhances translation of oncogenic TOP-ribosomal proteins, promoting liver cancer cell growth, migration, and invasion. LARP1 expression was increased in human NASH and HCC, suggesting a role in disease progression.
population_specificity: Mat1a knockout mice, liver cancer cell lines, and human liver specimens (NASH and HCC patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of AMD1 activity and spermidine in PM2.5 exposure-induced neuronal apoptosis.
results_summary: PM2.5 exposure reduced AMD1 expression and spermidine synthesis, triggering neuronal apoptosis. Spermidine supplementation rescued neurotoxicity and inhibited apoptosis via mitochondrial pathways.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 male mice, PC12 cells, and primary hippocampal neurons.
effective_dosage: PM2.5 concentrations of 0, 25, 50, 100, 200, and 400 μg/mL for in vitro studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how methionine and S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) maintain mTORC1 signaling activity in mammary epithelial cells under oxidative stress.
results_summary: The study found that H2O2 promoted SAM synthesis and reduced its utilization for methylation, while methionine and SAM activated mTORC1 under oxidative stress, independent of SAM transmethylation inhibition. This suggests SAM helps protect mammary cells against oxidative stress by sustaining mTORC1 signaling.
population_specificity: Mammary epithelial cells (in vitro) and mammary glands in vivo (animal model, likely mice or rats).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) could improve age- and obesity-related inflammatory and affective measures in the hippocampus of mice.
results_summary: SAMe treatment significantly improved fasting glucose, liver glutathione levels, and hippocampal microglia morphology in aged control mice, while also reducing anxiety-like behavior in obese mice, though effects were more subdued in the latter group.
population_specificity: Aged (14-month-old) and obese mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationships between S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) and non-coding RNAs (miRNAs/lncRNAs) in human cancer to develop more effective anticancer therapies.
results_summary: The study found that AdoMet and miRNAs/lncRNAs interact through epigenetic mechanisms, influencing DNA methylation and histone modifications, which could lead to innovative anticancer strategies. The review highlights the potential of targeting these interactions for therapeutic development.
population_specificity: Human cancer (broadly discussed, no specific patient group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe) in alleviating post-concussive sequelae in military mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) by reviewing preclinical and clinical literature.
results_summary: The review found evidence supporting SAMe's potential for improving symptoms like depression, pain, fatigue, and cognitive issues in mTBI, with favorable safety and tolerability. However, limitations included variability in patient presentations and unregulated SAMe product quality.
population_specificity: Military personnel with mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI), though findings may extend to civilian populations.
interactions: Potential for mania in patients with bipolar disorder; otherwise, none mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) supplementation could regulate AT1R-associated protein (ATRAP) and ameliorate steatosis in NAFLD.
results_summary: SAM supplementation was found to upregulate ATRAP expression, improve steatosis, and influence HuR-mediated nucleocytoplasmic shuttling of ATRAP mRNA, suggesting potential benefits for NAFLD treatment.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-fed C57BL/6 rats and L02 cells treated with oleic acid (OA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) modulates miRNA-34c and miRNA-449a expression in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells and enhances its antitumor effects.
results_summary: AdoMet upregulated miR-34c and miR-449a expression in TNBC cells, enhanced apoptosis via caspase-dependent mechanisms, and inhibited cell migration, with stronger effects when combined with miRNA mimics. These effects were linked to modulation of β-catenin and SMAD signaling pathways.
population_specificity: MDA-MB-231 and MDA-MB-468 triple-negative breast cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) in suppressing KSHV lytic replication and its connection to METTL16-mediated RNA methylation and redox homeostasis.
results_summary: SAM treatment inhibited KSHV lytic replication and reversed the effects of METTL16 or MAT2A knockdown by maintaining intracellular SAM levels and redox homeostasis. The study demonstrated that SAM's modulation of the methionine-SAM cycle is crucial for controlling viral replication.
population_specificity: Oncogenic Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) in vitro model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antitumor activity of S-adenosylmethionine (AdoMet) in Laryngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma (LSCC) and explore its underlying mechanisms, including epigenetic regulation via miRNAs.
results_summary: AdoMet induced ROS generation, autophagy, ER-stress, and UPR signaling in LSCC cells. It also downregulated miR-888-5p, and combining AdoMet with a miR-888-5p inhibitor synergistically enhanced apoptosis and inhibited cell migration by upregulating MYCBP and CDH1 genes.
population_specificity: Laryngeal Squamous Cell Carcinoma (LSCC) cell lines (JHU-SCC-011 and HNO210).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of saw palmetto in the development of a retroperitoneal hematoma (RPH) and highlight the underreported risks of herbal supplements.
results_summary: The study reported a case where saw palmetto use was associated with a retroperitoneal hematoma, suggesting it may contribute to bleeding risks, though causality was not definitively established. The abstract emphasizes the need for greater awareness of supplement-related risks in clinical practice.
population_specificity: A middle-aged male with a history of bilateral inguinal hernia repair.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of β-sitosterol enriched saw palmetto oil compared to conventional saw palmetto oil and placebo in treating benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH) and androgen deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that β-sitosterol enriched saw palmetto oil significantly improved BPH symptoms (reduced IPSS, PSA, and 5α-reductase levels) and androgen deficiency (increased free testosterone, improved AMS and ADAM scores) compared to placebo and conventional saw palmetto oil.
population_specificity: Men aged 40-65 years with symptomatic BPH.
effective_dosage: 500 mg doses orally in capsule form.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining saw palmetto oil with tamsulosin and pumpkin seed oil in a nanostructured lipid carrier could enhance permeation and therapeutic activity for treating benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
results_summary: The study found that the optimized TM-S/P-NLC formulation improved drug release (81% vs. 59% without S/P oil) and pharmacokinetic profile, while also showing favorable in vivo results for prostate weight and index reduction in BPH treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro models based on context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saw palmetto oil and its main components (lauric acid and myristic acid) could inhibit biofilm formation and reduce virulence in Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli O157:H7, and Candida albicans.
results_summary: Saw palmetto oil and its main components inhibited biofilm formation in single-, dual-, and three-species biofilms without affecting planktonic cell growth. They also reduced microbial virulence in a nematode infection model and showed synergistic effects with antibiotics against S. aureus and E. coli O157:H7.
population_specificity: In vitro and nematode infection model (Caenorhabditis elegans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a standardized saw palmetto extract could alleviate symptoms of andropause, including metabolic syndrome, reduced muscle endurance, and decreased spermatogenesis in aging rats.
results_summary: Saw palmetto supplementation reduced body weight gain, visceral fat, and serum lipid levels while increasing muscle endurance, sperm counts, and testosterone biosynthesis via hormonal regulation and gene activation in Leydig cells.
population_specificity: 24-week-old male Sprague Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of Saw Palmetto supplements for treating alopecia, including androgenetic alopecia and telogen effluvium.
results_summary: The study found that Saw Palmetto supplements (100-320 mg) improved hair quality (60%), total hair count (27%), and hair density (83.3%), while stabilizing disease progression in 52% of patients. It was well tolerated with no serious adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Patients with androgenetic alopecia (AGA) and telogen effluvium.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a 12-week treatment with saw palmetto berry extract (SPE) in alleviating lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in adult women.
results_summary: The study found that SPE significantly reduced daytime frequency and nocturia symptoms in women with LUTS, as measured by the CLSS and OABSS questionnaires, compared to placebo. The improvements were particularly notable in a subgroup with higher baseline symptom severity.
population_specificity: Adult women with urinary symptoms, specifically those with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the formation of nano-sized liposomes encapsulating saw palmetto CO₂ extract and assess their potential as a drug delivery system for treating hair loss.
results_summary: The study found that saw palmetto CO₂ extract was successfully encapsulated in nanoliposomes with a mean size of 145±5 nm, homogeneous dispersion, and negative charge. These liposomes could be suitable for delivering the extract to treat hair loss by inhibiting the 5α-reductase enzyme.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Saw Palmetto extract (SPE) in improving lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and explore its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that SPE showed inconsistent efficacy, partly due to lack of standardization, but a hexane extract (rich in free fatty acids) provided more consistent results. Free fatty acids and phytosterols in SPE demonstrated anti-androgenic and anti-inflammatory effects, suggesting multiple mechanisms may contribute to its benefits.
population_specificity: Elderly men with BPH-related LUTS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the silver variety of Serenoa repens (saw palmetto) as a qualitative substitute for the wild variety to support conservation efforts.
results_summary: The study compared tissue microstructures, lipid and water distribution, and metabolite profiles between the wild and silver varieties, proposing the silver variety as a potential substitute. The combined approach of 3D imaging and metabolomics provided new insights into phenotypic traits and metabolite synthesis.
population_specificity: Not specified (plant tissue analysis, not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of β-sitosterol enriched saw palmetto oil (VISPO) and conventional saw palmetto oil (SPO) in alleviating BPH complications using a testosterone-induced BPH rat model.
results_summary: VISPO showed superior efficacy compared to SPO, significantly reducing prostate weight-to-body weight ratio, serum testosterone levels, and improving prostate tissue histology. It also regulated inflammatory and apoptotic markers more effectively.
population_specificity: Testosterone-induced BPH model rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a formulated food containing saw palmetto extract (SPE) combined with Peucedanum japonicum extract on lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in male patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in quality of life (IPSS-QOL), nocturia frequency, and residual urine volume, with slight improvements in other subjective symptoms and objective parameters like PSA and urinary 8-OHdG levels. No adverse reactions were reported, and 75% of patients rated the treatment as "Good" or higher.
population_specificity: Male patients with untreated lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS).

study_goal: To assess the clinical efficacy of saw palmetto fruit extract (SPFE) in improving lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in patients with type ⅢA prostatitis.
results_summary: SPFE significantly improved NIH-CPSI, IPSS, urodynamic parameters, and voiding diary metrics, with no reported adverse reactions. The treatment led to clinically meaningful reductions in symptoms and improved urinary function.
population_specificity: 54 male patients (aged 35.06 ± 5.85 years) with type ⅢA prostatitis and a mean disease course of 3.8 ± 2.1 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the anti-tumor potential of the red pigmented aqueous fraction of Saw Palmetto (NYG) on human hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and its possible targets.
results_summary: NYG significantly inhibited tumor growth in a dose-dependent manner in both subcutaneous xenograft and orthotopic HCC models. It reduced endothelial cell migration, tube formation, and intratumoral neovascularization, likely by attenuating ERK activation, but had no direct effect on HCC cell viability or VEGF secretion.
population_specificity: Human hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cell lines, human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVEC), and mouse models (subcutaneous xenograft and orthotopic implantation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the in vitro potency of a novel supercritical CO2 extract of Saw Palmetto (SPSE) in inhibiting the 5α-reductase type II enzyme, compared to finasteride.
results_summary: SPSE demonstrated competitive binding to the 5α-reductase type II enzyme, with a half-maximal inhibitory concentration of 3.58±0.05 μg/mL, and its bioactivity was comparable to finasteride and superior to many other phytotherapeutic extracts. The study concluded that SPSE effectively inhibits the enzyme linked to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
population_specificity: In vitro cell-free test system (no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (in vitro concentration used: 3.58±0.05 μg/mL for half-maximal inhibition).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Saw Palmetto supplements (SPS) with varying fatty acids and phytosterols concentrations inhibit growth in androgen-sensitive LNCaP cells and hamster flank organs.
results_summary: High long-chain fatty acids-low phytosterols (HLLP) SPS showed mixed effects on LNCaP cell growth, while high long-chain fatty acids-high phytosterols (HLHP) and high medium-chain fatty acids-low phytosterols (HMLP) SPS significantly reduced cell numbers. In hamsters, SPS caused a nonsignificant reduction in flank organ growth with testosterone but not dihydrotestosterone.
population_specificity: Androgen-sensitive LNCaP cells and castrated male Syrian hamsters.
effective_dosage: ≥500 nM to ≥750 nM for LNCaP cells; applied topically daily for hamsters.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of Saw Palmetto Extract Capsules in treating benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in IPSS, QOL, urinary flow rate, and postvoid residual urine after 12 weeks of treatment, with only one mild adverse event reported.
population_specificity: 165 BPH patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of saw palmetto extract on glioma cell metastasis, antiangiogenesis, and its mechanism through the STAT3 signaling pathway.
results_summary: Saw palmetto extract inhibited the proliferation of human glioma cells, increased apoptosis, reduced pSTAT3 levels, and inhibited angiogenesis (CD34). It may serve as an adjunctive therapeutic agent for glioma and other cancers with activated STAT3 signaling.
population_specificity: Human glioma cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety, maximum tolerated dose, and preliminary efficacy of saw palmetto for managing lower urinary tract symptoms during radiation therapy for prostate cancer.
results_summary: The study found saw palmetto at 960 mg daily was safe with no dose-limiting toxicities, but no statistically significant improvements in urinary symptoms were observed. However, quality of life related to prostate-specific concerns improved in the saw palmetto group.
population_specificity: Men undergoing radiation therapy for prostate cancer experiencing lower urinary tract symptoms.
effective_dosage: 320 mg, 640 mg, and 960 mg daily (MTD was 960 mg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic applications of Saw Palmetto fruit extract (SPE) for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), prostate cancer, and chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome, including its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that SPE has therapeutic effects on BPH, lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS), chronic prostatitis, prostate cancer, and sexual dysfunction, with a discussion on its action mechanisms.
population_specificity: Patients with BPH, prostate cancer, chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome, and related conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of BYSH, a herbal formula, in patients with advanced hormone-refractory prostate cancer (HRPC).
results_summary: Most patients had stable PSA levels during BYSH treatment, but PSA levels increased by the end of the study. The median survival was 16.4 months, and no adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced hormone-refractory prostate cancer (HRPC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of saw palmetto extract on urodynamic parameters, bladder receptors, and urinary cytokines in rats with cyclophosphamide-induced cystitis.
results_summary: Saw palmetto extract improved urodynamic parameters, attenuated receptor binding decreases, and suppressed elevated urinary cytokine levels in rats with cystitis.
population_specificity: Rats with cyclophosphamide-induced cystitis
effective_dosage: 60 mg/kg per day, administered orally twice daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether combining Saw Palmetto (Serenoa repens) with antibiotics improves outcomes in chronic bacterial prostatitis compared to antibiotics alone.
results_summary: The study found that combining Saw Palmetto with antibiotics significantly reduced recurrence rates (7.8% vs. 27.6%) and improved symptom scores compared to antibiotics alone. The supplement group also showed better control of symptoms and lower serum PSA levels.
population_specificity: 210 patients with chronic bacterial prostatitis (symptoms >3 months, Meares-Stamey test positive).
effective_dosage: Serenoa repens 320 mg daily (combined with Lactobacillus Sporogens 200 mg and Arbutin 100 mg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare two analytical methods (gas chromatography and NMR spectroscopy) to assess the chemical variability and quality of 57 different saw palmetto products.
results_summary: The study found high heterogeneity in fatty acid composition among saw palmetto products. NMR spectroscopy effectively differentiated products based on extraction methods but not within similar extraction groups.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on product analysis, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saw palmetto extract (SPE) relaxes corpus cavernosum and explore its mechanisms, particularly its potential for preventing or treating erectile dysfunction.
results_summary: SPE dose-dependently enhanced the relaxant response to electrical stimulation in corpus cavernosum, inhibited PDE5 activity, and increased iNOS mRNA expression, similar to sildenafil's effects. PDE5 mRNA was only significantly enhanced at the middle SPE dose.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats and New Zealand rabbits.
effective_dosage: Low-, middle-, and high-dose SPE (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saw palmetto fruit extracts affect in vitro adipogenesis by modulating key factors involved in adipocyte differentiation.
results_summary: Saw palmetto ethanol extract inhibited lipid droplet accumulation in a dose-dependent manner, reduced protein expressions of C-EBPα and PPARγ, and decreased phosphorylation of Erk1/2 and Akt1, suggesting it selectively affects adipocyte differentiation.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether higher doses of saw palmetto affect serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels in men with lower urinary tract symptoms.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in serum PSA levels between the saw palmetto and placebo groups, even at high doses (up to 960 mg). Saw palmetto did not influence PSA levels more than placebo.
population_specificity: Men older than 45 years with an AUA symptom score of 8 to 24.
effective_dosage: 320 mg for 24 weeks, 640 mg for the next 24 weeks, and 960 mg for the final 24 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess participant perception of treatment assignment and the effectiveness of saw palmetto in treating benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) symptoms in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial.
results_summary: The study found that blinding was successful, with no significant difference in treatment assignment guesses between saw palmetto and placebo groups. Participants who experienced symptom improvement were more likely to believe they were taking saw palmetto, regardless of actual assignment.
population_specificity: Men aged 45 and older with moderate to low severe BPH symptoms.
effective_dosage: 320 mg gelcaps daily for the first 24 weeks, 640 mg daily for the next 24 weeks, and 960 mg daily for the final 24 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate a potential link between saw palmetto use and acute pancreatitis in a patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia.
results_summary: The study reported a case of acute pancreatitis possibly linked to saw palmetto use, with symptoms resolving after discontinuation. The authors concluded that a causal relationship is plausible and advised caution.
population_specificity: A 61-year-old Caucasian man with benign prostatic hyperplasia and gastroesophageal reflux disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saw palmetto berry preparation (Prostasan®) improved benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) symptoms and sexual dysfunctions (SDys) in elderly men.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in BPH symptoms (reduced International Prostate Symptom Score) and SDys (improved Sexual Function Inventory and QoL scores), with high efficacy and good tolerability. Both investigators and patients confirmed the positive outcomes.
population_specificity: Elderly men with mild to moderate BPH.
effective_dosage: 320 mg saw palmetto extract daily (one capsule).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the genotoxic potential of saw palmetto, specifically its ability to induce DNA lesions, gene mutations, chromosomal mutations, or mitotic recombination in Drosophila melanogaster.
results_summary: Saw palmetto induced significant increases in spot frequencies in trans-heterozygous flies, indicating it acts as a specific inducer of homologous recombination in proliferative cells, an event linked to loss of heterozygosity. However, no increment in total spot frequencies was observed in balancer-heterozygous flies compared to the negative control.
population_specificity: Drosophila melanogaster (fruit flies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the in vitro potency of a novel saw palmetto ethanol extract (SPET-085) as an inhibitor of the 5alpha-reductase type II enzyme, comparing it to finasteride.
results_summary: SPET-085 effectively inhibited 5alpha-reductase type II in vitro (IC50=2.88±0.45 µg/mL) and was more effective than other saw palmetto extracts, with comparable efficacy to finasteride. The study concluded that SPET-085 has prostate health-promoting bioactivity similar to the prescription drug standard.
population_specificity: In vitro cell-free test system (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saw palmetto could cause acute pancreatitis in a patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
results_summary: The study found that saw palmetto likely caused acute pancreatitis in a 65-year-old male with BPH, marking the second documented case of this adverse effect. The mechanism may involve estrogenic receptor stimulation, triglyceride elevation, or cyclooxygenase inhibition.
population_specificity: A 65-year-old male with a history of diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, gout, Barrett esophagitis, and chronic gastritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (one week of use mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of saw palmetto oil, alone and in combination with pumpkin seed oil, as a complementary treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia.
results_summary: Saw palmetto oil alone improved international prostate symptom scores by 3 months, quality of life scores by 3 months, and maximal urinary flow rate by 12 months, but combined treatment with pumpkin seed oil did not show significant additional benefits.
population_specificity: 47 benign prostatic hyperplasia patients with an average age of 53.3 years and international prostate symptom scores over 8.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a composition containing LSESr (Saw Palmetto extract) and anti-inflammatory agents could alter inflammatory markers in hair follicle keratinocytes.
results_summary: The composition effectively suppressed LPS-activated gene expression of inflammatory chemokines (CCL17, CXCL6, LTB(4)), suggesting anti-inflammatory effects in hair follicle keratinocytes. The findings support a potential dual approach combining 5-alpha reductase inhibition and anti-inflammatory action for treating androgenetic alopecia.
population_specificity: In vitro cultured human keratinocyte cells (not a human trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the main active components in Saw Palmetto extract (SPE) responsible for binding to alpha(1)-adrenergic, muscarinic, and 1,4-DHP receptors and inhibiting 5alpha-reductase.
results_summary: The study found that oleic and lauric acids in SPE actively bind to key receptors in the prostate and bladder, mimicking the effects of SPE. These fatty acids also inhibited 5alpha-reductase, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for benign prostatic hyperplasia and related urinary symptoms.
population_specificity: Rats (prostate and bladder tissue)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety profile of Serenoa repens (saw palmetto) monopreparations, focusing on adverse events and drug interactions in humans.
results_summary: The study found that saw palmetto is generally well-tolerated, with adverse events being mild, infrequent, and reversible, similar to placebo. No drug interactions were reported, though causality for rare serious adverse events remains questionable.
population_specificity: Humans using saw palmetto monopreparations for lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacological effects and safety of Saw Palmetto extract (SPE) in treating urinary dysfunction due to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and associated lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS).
results_summary: The study found that SPE may improve urinary dysfunction by binding to receptors in the lower urinary tract, such as alpha(1)-adrenoceptors and muscarinic cholinoceptors, and attenuating receptor up-regulation. Clinical trials suggested SPE is safe with no serious adverse events or significant drug interactions.
population_specificity: Men with BPH and associated lower urinary tract symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential toxicity and safety profile of saw palmetto in men with moderate-to-severe benign prostatic hyperplasia symptoms.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in serious or non-serious adverse events between saw palmetto and placebo groups, with only minor laboratory differences observed. No evidence of serious toxicity was detected, though rare adverse effects could not be ruled out.
population_specificity: 225 men with moderate-to-severe benign prostatic hyperplasia symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of saw palmetto (LESP) on sexual activity in male rats, comparing it with D-004 and a control group.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in sexual activity behavior (mounts, intromissions, latencies) between rats treated with saw palmetto (at 400 or 800 mg/kg) and the control group, whether administered as a single dose or over 30 days. No adverse events or toxicity were observed.
population_specificity: Adult male Wistar rats (mean age 10 weeks, mean weight 295 g)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Saw Palmetto Berry Extract (SPBE) and its sterol components (beta-sitosterol and stigmasterol) inhibit prostate cancer growth and migration by modulating p53, p21, and p27 protein expression.
results_summary: SPBE and its sterol components inhibited prostate cancer growth by increasing p53 expression and reduced carcinoma development by decreasing p21 and p27 expression. However, these effects were reversed and even enhanced in the presence of cholesterol. The study also observed that increased p53 expression led to greater intracellular force generation, suggesting a dual role for p53.
population_specificity: DU-145 prostate cancer cells (in vitro study)
interactions: Cholesterol reversed the anti-tumor effects of SPBE and its sterol components.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Prostataplex (containing Saw Palmetto) on lower urinary tract symptoms associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia in men.
results_summary: Prostataplex significantly improved maximum urinary flow rate and reduced relative urinary resistance compared to placebo. While prostate volume and International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) did not differ significantly between groups, 39.1% of treated patients showed IPSS improvement versus 2.2% in the control group.
population_specificity: 92 Chinese men aged 49-75 with lower urinary tract symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and toxicity of saw palmetto extract at varying doses over an 18-month period in men with lower urinary tract symptoms due to benign prostatic hyperplasia.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in adverse events, vital signs, or laboratory test abnormalities between saw palmetto and placebo groups, indicating no evidence of toxicity. However, efficacy was not superior to placebo.
population_specificity: Men with lower urinary tract symptoms due to benign prostatic hyperplasia.
effective_dosage: 320, 640, and 960 mg daily of an ethanolic saw palmetto extract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Saw Palmetto (SW) has genotoxic effects or causes chromatin conformation modifications in mouse bone marrow cells.
