results_summary: The study found that Saw Palmetto increased nuclear heterogeneity in bone marrow cells in a dose-dependent manner but did not cause genotoxic effects (no increase in micronucleated blood cells). The changes were attributed to chromatin conformation modifications rather than DNA damage.
population_specificity: Male and female mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the binding affinities of major fatty acids in Saw Palmetto extract (SPE) for alpha(1)-adrenergic, muscarinic, and 1,4-DHP receptors, as well as their inhibitory effects on 5alpha-reductase activity.
results_summary: The study found that lauric acid, oleic acid, myristic acid, and linoleic acid in SPE exhibited binding activities for alpha(1)-adrenergic, muscarinic, and 1,4-DHP receptors and inhibited 5alpha-reductase activity, with palmitic acid showing no effect on muscarinic receptors or 5alpha-reductase inhibition.
population_specificity: Rat brain and liver tissues
effective_dosage: IC(50) values ranged from 23.8 to 169 microg/ml for receptor binding and 42.1 to 101 microg/ml for 5alpha-reductase inhibition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-prostate cancer activity of Saw Palmetto, including its effects on cell growth, apoptosis, and molecular pathways.
results_summary: Saw Palmetto induced growth arrest and apoptosis in prostate cancer cells, down-regulated androgen receptor and PSA expression, and inhibited tumor growth in mice without adverse effects.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer cell lines (LNCaP, DU145, PC3) and BALB/c nude mice with LNCaP xenografts.
effective_dosage: ED50s of approximately 2.0, 2.6, and 3.3 microl/ml for LNCaP, DU145, and PC3 cells, respectively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saw palmetto extract (SPE) could prevent prostate cancer progression in a transgenic mouse model by evaluating its effects on tumor grade, apoptosis, and androgen levels.
results_summary: Treatment with 300 mg/kg/day SPE significantly reduced prostate DHT levels, increased apoptosis, decreased tumor grade, and reduced tumor incidence in TRAMP mice. Lower doses showed less pronounced effects.
population_specificity: Transgenic adenocarcinoma of the mouse prostate (TRAMP) model mice.
effective_dosage: 50 mg/kg/day and 300 mg/kg/day SPE administered in diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saw palmetto extract improves symptoms and objective measures of benign prostatic hyperplasia compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference between saw palmetto and placebo in improving symptoms, urinary flow rate, prostate size, residual volume, quality of life, or prostate-specific antigen levels. The incidence of side effects was similar in both groups.
population_specificity: 225 men over 49 years with moderate-to-severe symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review documented interactions between saw palmetto and prescription drugs, focusing on its potential for adverse interactions.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results about saw palmetto's effects but highlights the potential for adverse interactions when used with prescription medications due to shared drug metabolizing enzyme systems.
population_specificity: Older adults (over age 50) with chronic diseases.
interactions: Potential for adverse interactions with prescription medications due to shared drug metabolizing enzyme systems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiandrogenic effects and clinical efficacy of saw palmetto, particularly its liposterolic extract, in treating benign prostatic hyperplasia with lower urinary tract symptoms.
results_summary: In vitro studies suggest saw palmetto may inhibit 5alpha-reductase, but clinical studies did not show reductions in serum dihydrotestosterone or prostate-specific antigen. One trial suggested equivalency to finasteride for symptom relief with fewer sexual side effects, but lack of placebo controls limits definitive efficacy conclusions.
population_specificity: Patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia and lower urinary tract symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the efficacy of second- and third-line treatments, including herbal supplements like Saw Palmetto, for chronic nonbacterial prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding Saw Palmetto's effects, only mentioning it as one of several treatments studied.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic nonbacterial prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Saw Palmetto berry lipid extract (SPLE) and astaxanthin on 5alpha-reductase inhibition and the growth of prostatic carcinoma cells in vitro.
results_summary: SPLE alone showed a 34% decrease in prostatic carcinoma cell growth at 0.1 mcg/mL, while its combination with astaxanthin (Alphastat) demonstrated 20% greater 5alpha-reductase inhibition than SPLE alone. Astaxanthin alone also significantly inhibited 5alpha-reductase and reduced cancer cell growth.
population_specificity: Human prostatic carcinoma cells (in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of saw palmetto in improving urinary function in men with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and compare it to tamsulosin.
results_summary: The study found that saw palmetto improved urinary function in men with BPH, with favorable comparisons to tamsulosin and minimal adverse effects, though the extent of placebo effects and the precise mechanism of action remain unclear.
population_specificity: Men with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of saw palmetto extract (SPE) on the micturition reflex and autonomic receptors in the lower urinary tract of rats.
results_summary: SPE increased micturition interval, volume, and bladder capacity in rats, reversed acetic acid-induced urinary dysfunction, and inhibited specific receptor binding in the bladder and prostate. The results suggest SPE may alleviate urodynamic symptoms in hyperactive bladders.
population_specificity: Anesthetized rats and conscious SHR/NDmc-cp (cp/cp) rats.
effective_dosage: 6 mg/kg daily (oral), 12 mg/kg, 20 mg/kg, and 60 mg/kg (intraduodenal).
study_duration: Not specified for anesthetized rats; repeat oral administration in conscious rats (duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saw palmetto extract (SPE) suppresses growth and induces apoptosis in prostate epithelial cells by inhibiting IGF-I signaling.
results_summary: SPE reduced IGF-I-induced proliferation and Akt phosphorylation, induced apoptosis markers, and activated the proapoptotic protein JNK, suggesting potential antiproliferative and proapoptotic effects on prostate epithelia. No effect was observed on IGF-I-induced phosphorylation of MAPK, IGF-IR, or Shc.
population_specificity: P69 prostate epithelial cell line (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of saw palmetto in treating symptoms related to benign prostatic hyperplasia and chronic prostatitis.
results_summary: Saw palmetto demonstrated efficacy similar to finasteride in reducing benign prostatic hyperplasia symptoms, with better tolerability and lower cost. No significant side effects or drug interactions were reported, but long-term usage data is unavailable.
population_specificity: Patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia or chronic prostatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of saw palmetto compared to finasteride in treating men with category III prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CP/CPPS).
results_summary: Saw palmetto showed no appreciable long-term improvement in CP/CPPS symptoms, with no significant changes in symptom scores. Adverse events were minimal (3 cases of headache), but efficacy was notably poor compared to finasteride.
population_specificity: Men aged 24-58 years (mean 43.2) diagnosed with CP/CPPS, previously treated with antibiotics and alpha-blockers.

study_goal: The researchers were investigating a case of sensitization to saw palmetto in a patient who had previously developed an allergy to topical minoxidil.
results_summary: The study found that the patient became sensitized to saw palmetto after using a topical preparation containing minoxidil and retinoic acid, suggesting a potential cross-reactivity or allergic response.
population_specificity: A 24-year-old woman with androgenetic alopecia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Saw Palmetto herbal blend (SPHB) affects nuclear DNA structure and organization in prostate epithelial cells, potentially explaining its therapeutic effects in benign prostatic hyperplasia.
results_summary: After 6 months of SPHB treatment, 25 of 60 nuclear morphometric descriptors significantly changed, suggesting altered DNA chromatin structure. A multivariate model predicted treatment effect with high accuracy (85%) and an area under the curve of 94%.
population_specificity: Men with symptomatic benign prostatic hyperplasia (n=20 treated, n=20 placebo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the pharmacological activities, clinical assessment, therapeutic efficacy, and safety profile of Saw Palmetto for managing benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and related lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS).
results_summary: The study found that Saw Palmetto has a favorable safety profile and therapeutic efficacy for managing BPH and LUTS, supported by broadening scientific evidence and clinical assessments.
population_specificity: Aging men with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and associated lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a saw palmetto herbal blend (SPHB) on prostatic tissue androgen levels compared to finasteride and evaluate the feasibility of using needle biopsies for such measurements.
results_summary: The study found that SPHB reduced prostatic tissue DHT levels by 32% in a randomized trial, a statistically significant effect (P <0.005), while placebo showed no significant change. The results suggest SPHB may inhibit 5-alpha reductase, similar to finasteride but with a more modest effect.
population_specificity: Men with symptomatic benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saw palmetto extracts act as alpha1-adrenoceptor antagonists in vivo in humans, as they do in vitro.
results_summary: Saw palmetto extracts did not show alpha1-adrenoceptor subtype occupancy in vivo, caused minor reductions in supine blood pressure but no significant effects during orthostatic stress or heart rate changes, and left plasma catecholamines largely unchanged.
population_specificity: 12 healthy young men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the cytotoxicity of Saw Palmetto Berry Extract (SPBE) on prostatic cell lines and its potential effects on cell proliferation and expression of cancer-related proteins.
results_summary: SPBE inhibited the proliferation of prostatic cell lines (267B-1, BRFF-41T, LNCaP) with varying IC50 values, and its effects were reversible. SPBE also reduced growth in non-prostatic cancer cell lines and decreased Cox-2 expression, suggesting potential benefits for BPH and prostate cancer chemoprevention.
population_specificity: Prostatic cell lines (267B-1, BRFF-41T, LNCaP) and non-prostatic cancer cell lines (Jurkat, HT-29).
effective_dosage: IC50 concentrations of 20-30 nl/ml for 267B-1 and BRFF-41T, ~10-fold higher for LNCaP; 200 nl/ml for normal prostate cells.
study_duration: 3 days for proliferation inhibition; 30 min for reversibility test.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a saw palmetto herbal blend on clinical and histological parameters in men with symptomatic benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
results_summary: The saw palmetto herbal blend showed slight clinical improvement over placebo (not statistically significant) but demonstrated significant epithelial contraction in the prostate transition zone (p <0.01) and increased atrophic glands (p <0.01). No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: 44 men aged 45-80 years with symptomatic BPH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on saw palmetto's mechanism of action and clinical effects in men with lower urinary tract symptoms due to benign prostatic hyperplasia.
results_summary: Saw palmetto demonstrated potential mechanisms like 5-alpha reductase inhibition and adrenergic receptor antagonism in vitro, but clinical relevance remains unclear. Placebo-controlled trials and meta-analyses suggested subjective and objective improvements, though studies were limited by methodological flaws and small sample sizes.
population_specificity: Men with lower urinary tract symptoms due to benign prostatic hyperplasia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saw palmetto extracts exhibit alpha1-adrenoceptor antagonistic properties in vitro, which could explain their therapeutic effects for lower urinary tract symptoms.
results_summary: Saw palmetto extracts inhibited radioligand binding to human alpha1-adrenoceptors and agonist-induced [3H]inositol phosphate formation, suggesting noncompetitive antagonism. The active concentrations in vitro were slightly lower than those of chemically defined alpha1-adrenoceptor antagonists.
population_specificity: Human prostatic alpha1-adrenoceptors (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze the therapeutic efficacy and safety of saw palmetto (Serenoa repens) in men with symptomatic benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
results_summary: Saw palmetto improved urinary tract symptom scores, nocturia, and peak urine flow compared to placebo, with effects similar to finasteride but fewer adverse events. Adverse effects were mild and infrequent, with lower rates of erectile dysfunction than finasteride.
population_specificity: Men with symptomatic BPH.
study_duration: Mean study duration was 9 weeks (range: 4-48 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of saw palmetto on voiding symptoms and urodynamic parameters in men with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) presumed secondary to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
results_summary: Saw palmetto significantly improved symptom scores (IPSS) over 6 months, with 46% of patients showing a 50% or greater improvement. However, no significant changes were observed in objective measures like peak urinary flow rate or postvoid residual volume.
population_specificity: 50 men with untreated LUTS and an IPSS of 10 or greater.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline standardized procedures for Scaling and Root Planing (SRP) to improve clinical efficacy and periodontal treatment outcomes.
results_summary: The study highlights SRP as a simple, effective, and cost-efficient treatment for managing periodontal inflammation, with evidence suggesting lifelong retention of natural teeth when combined with rigorous plaque control and long-term supportive care. However, it notes variability in practitioner proficiency and standardization in China.
population_specificity: Adults in China with periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (a-PDT) as an adjunct to scaling and root planing (SRP) in improving clinical and biochemical parameters in chronic periodontitis patients.
results_summary: The study found that SRP combined with a-PDT (group 2) showed significant improvement in clinical (plaque index, gingival index, probing pocket depth) and biochemical (total antioxidant capacity, total oxidative status, oxidative stress index) parameters compared to SRP alone (group 1) at 3 months, though no significant difference was observed in clinical attachment level.
population_specificity: 40 chronic periodontitis patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of laser-assisted new attachment method (LANAP) combined with scaling and root planing (SRP) in treating moderate to deep periodontal pockets compared to SRP alone.
results_summary: The study found that LANAP combined with SRP resulted in statistically significant reductions in periodontal pocket depth (PPD) and clinical attachment level (CAL) compared to SRP alone at both six and twenty-four weeks. The test group showed clinically significant improvements, suggesting LANAP may enhance the benefits of SRP.
population_specificity: Ten participants aged 18-65 with moderate to deep periodontal pockets.
study_duration: Six and twenty-four weeks post-intervention assessments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Guided Biofilm Therapy (GBT) versus traditional Scaling and Root Planing (SRP) in achieving pocket closure in patients with stages III and IV periodontitis.
results_summary: Both GBT and SRP showed comparable reductions in pocket probing depth and similar rates of closed pockets at 6 weeks and 3 months, with no statistically or clinically significant differences between the treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with stages III and IV periodontitis.
study_duration: 3 months (with assessments at 6 weeks and 3 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saw palmetto affects the activity of cytochrome P450 enzymes CYP2D6 or CYP3A4, which are involved in drug metabolism.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of saw palmetto on CYP2D6 or CYP3A4 activity, suggesting it is unlikely to alter the metabolism of drugs dependent on these pathways. The results were consistent across both enzymes, with no statistically significant changes observed.
population_specificity: 12 healthy volunteers (6 men and 6 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of scaling and root planing (SRP) alone versus SRP combined with an oxygen-releasing gel (BlueM oral gel) in treating chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: Both groups showed reductions in probing pocket depth, clinical attachment level, gingival index, and bleeding on probing, but the group receiving SRP with the oxygen-releasing gel demonstrated statistically significant greater improvements in these clinical parameters.
population_specificity: 25 systemically healthy participants with chronic periodontitis (50 sites total, split-mouth design).
effective_dosage: Not specified (placement of BlueM oral gel after SRP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical effectiveness of subgingivally delivered 0.5% azithromycin gel and 1% chlorhexidine gel as adjuncts to scaling and root planing (SRP) in managing chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: Both adjunct therapies improved clinical parameters, but 0.5% azithromycin gel showed superior outcomes, with greater reductions in probing pocket depth (2.5 mm vs. 1.8 mm) and higher gains in clinical attachment level (2.3 mm vs. 1.5 mm) compared to 1% chlorhexidine gel.
population_specificity: 60 participants diagnosed with chronic periodontitis.
effective_dosage: 0.5% azithromycin gel and 1% chlorhexidine gel, subgingivally applied after SRP.

study_goal: To evaluate the application of mixed reality holographic imaging technology in improving the effectiveness of scaling and root planing for patients with advanced periodontitis.
results_summary: MR hologram-assisted SRP significantly reduced probing pocket depth, clinical attachment loss, plaque index, and bleeding on probing at 8 weeks post-treatment. Patients reported better perception of treatment effectiveness and 80% expressed willingness to undergo MR-assisted treatment in the future.
population_specificity: 10 patients with advanced periodontitis (1566 sites from 261 teeth).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of folic acid and chlorhexidine mouthwash as adjuncts to scaling and root planing in treating chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: Both folic acid and chlorhexidine mouthrinses significantly improved clinical parameters (plaque index, gingival index, probing pocket depth, and healing index) when used alongside scaling and root planing. The study concluded that both treatments were effective adjuncts for periodontitis management.
population_specificity: 30 patients with chronic periodontitis.

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of platelet-rich fibrin (PRF) as an adjunct to scaling and root planing (ScRp) for healing shallow periodontal pockets.
results_summary: PRF adjunct to ScRp showed greater clinical attachment gains, probing pocket depth reductions, and increased PDGF-BB levels in gingival crevicular fluid compared to ScRp alone at 1- and 3-month follow-ups. The improvements were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Twelve patients with periodontitis and shallow periodontal pockets (4-6 mm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether rose bengal-mediated antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (a-PDT) as an adjunct to scaling and root planing (SRP) improves clinical and microbiological outcomes in chronic periodontitis patients compared to SRP alone.
results_summary: The study found that SRP combined with a-PDT significantly improved gingival index, probing pocket depth, clinical attachment level, and reduced microbial counts (including red complex organisms) compared to SRP alone at the 3-month follow-up.
population_specificity: 30 patients with chronic periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different laser modalities in non-surgical periodontal treatment with traditional Scaling and Root Planing (SRP).
results_summary: The study found that SRP reduces microbial load and inflammation, improving clinical outcomes, but noted limitations in accessing certain anatomical areas. Advanced laser systems showed potential benefits in reaching these areas and enhancing treatment efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of scaling and root planing (SRP) with and without placental extract gel in treating chronic localized periodontitis under magnification.
results_summary: Placental extract gel combined with SRP showed significant improvement in clinical parameters (pocket probing depth, relative attachment level, gingival index, and bleeding on probing) compared to SRP alone. The study concluded that placental extract gel may enhance the therapeutic effects of SRP in localized periodontal pockets.
population_specificity: 20 systemically healthy patients with chronic localized periodontitis (40 sites total).
study_duration: 3 months (evaluations at baseline, 6 weeks, and 3 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of 1.2% rosuvastatin hydrogel as an adjunct to scaling and root planing (SRP) in managing generalized chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: The study found that SRP combined with 1.2% rosuvastatin hydrogel (Group B) led to significantly greater improvements in clinical parameters (mSBI, PPD, CAL) compared to SRP alone (Group A) after three months. The adjunctive use of RSV hydrogel enhanced periodontal therapy outcomes.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with generalized chronic periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of laser-assisted periodontal therapy (LAPT) to conventional scaling and root planing (SRP) in treating periodontal disease.
results_summary: The study found that LAPT resulted in a greater mean reduction in pocket depth (2.5 mm vs. 2.0 mm) and a greater mean improvement in clinical attachment level (1.8 mm vs. 1.3 mm) compared to conventional SRP, with statistically significant differences.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontal disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of local curcumin application as an adjunct to scaling and root planing on clinical and microbiologic parameters in periodontitis patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in clinical parameters within a month when curcumin chips were used alongside scaling and root planing, along with reductions in red complex microorganisms. The review suggested curcumin as a viable adjunct but called for further research on optimal dosing and delivery.
population_specificity: Periodontitis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of laser-assisted periodontal therapy (LAPT) with conventional scaling and root planing (CSRP) in treating periodontal disease.
results_summary: Both LAPT and CSRP significantly improved periodontal health, with LAPT showing slightly greater reductions in probing depth (2.5 mm vs. 2.2 mm) and clinical attachment level gains (2.8 mm vs. 2.5 mm). The improvements were statistically significant (P < 0.05) for both treatments.
population_specificity: 60 patients diagnosed with periodontal disease, divided into two groups of 30 each (LAPT and CSRP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of photodynamic therapy (PDT) as an adjunct to scaling and root planing (SRP) on clinical parameters and microbial composition in periodontitis patients.
results_summary: The study found that repeated PDT adjunct to SRP significantly improved probing pocket depth, altered microbial composition (reducing anaerobic bacteria and increasing aerobic bacteria), and decreased periodontopathogens while increasing beneficial bacteria. Both single and repeated PDT applications showed positive effects compared to SRP alone.
population_specificity: Seventeen periodontitis patients with probing pocket depth ≥5 mm and bleeding on probing.
effective_dosage: Single PDT application right after SRP or three repeated PDT applications 1 week after SRP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effect of adjunctive 980 nm diode laser therapy alongside scaling and root planing in patients with chronic periodontitis and type II diabetes.
results_summary: The test group (scaling and root planing plus laser therapy) showed significant improvement in gingival and plaque indices compared to the control group (scaling and root planing alone). While probing pocket depth and clinical attachment did not show significant improvement, the test group still performed better than the control.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic periodontitis and type II diabetes (20 participants in a split-mouth study design).
study_duration: Three months (with measurements at baseline, six weeks, and three months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of virtual reality distraction (VRD) on dental anxiety during scaling and root planing (SRP) in periodontitis patients.
results_summary: VRD significantly reduced pain and discomfort levels (VASP) during SRP, and starting treatment without VRD initially decreased anxiety and increased immersion. Most patients (63.3%) preferred VRD in subsequent treatments, with preference correlating with age but not sex.
population_specificity: 60 periodontitis patients with dental anxiety (DAS score ≥9) requiring SRP in at least two quadrants with probing depth ≥4mm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Nd:YAG laser-assisted SRP on glucose control and subgingival microbiome changes in periodontitis patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Nd:YAG laser-assisted SRP significantly improved periodontal inflammation and glycemic control compared to SRP alone, with favorable shifts in subgingival microbiome composition. Both groups showed significant improvement in bleeding on probing (BOP), but the Nd:YAG group had better outcomes in probing depth (PD) and clinical attachment level (CAL).
population_specificity: 22 patients with periodontitis and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficiency of three different antioxidants as oral supplements alongside Scaling and Root Planing (SRP) in treating chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: All groups showed statistically significant reductions in pocket depth (PD) and clinical attachment level (CAL), with green coffee bean extract demonstrating the most significant reduction in PD. No significant improvements were observed in oral hygiene index-simplified (OHI-S) or sulcus bleeding index (SBI).
population_specificity: Eighty patients with chronic periodontitis (stage III grade B).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine changes in LXA4 levels in GCF after SRP and determine the relationship between LXA4 levels, treatment outcomes, and periodontal pathogens in severe periodontitis.
results_summary: LXA4 levels in GCF significantly increased after SRP but remained lower than in healthy individuals. Lower baseline LXA4 predicted greater improvements in PD, and higher post-treatment LXA4 correlated with clinical improvements and reduced presence of specific periodontal pathogens.
population_specificity: 21 severe periodontitis participants and 25 periodontally healthy participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of probiotics and tetracycline fibers as adjunctive treatments after Scaling and Root Planing (SRP) on IL1β levels in type 2 diabetic patients with periodontitis.
results_summary: All groups showed improvement in clinical and biochemical parameters, with the most significant results in well-controlled diabetics (Group IIA). Adjunctive local drug delivery after SRP was not beneficial for uncontrolled diabetics (Group I).
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic patients with periodontitis (controlled and uncontrolled) and non-diabetic patients with periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Sterify Gel as an adjunctive treatment to Scaling and Root Planing (SRP) in promoting the healing of periodontal pockets.
results_summary: Sterify Gel combined with SRP showed significant improvements in pocket depth, gingival recession, and clinical attachment level compared to SRP alone, with a reduction in bacterial contamination at 3 months. No significant differences were observed in bleeding and plaque indexes, pain perception, tooth mobility, or furcations between the two groups.
population_specificity: 34 patients with moderate to advanced chronic periodontal disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of powered versus manual toothbrushing after scaling and root planing on clinical indicators of periodontitis, such as bleeding on probing, plaque levels, and probing pocket depth.
results_summary: The study found that powered toothbrushing combined with scaling and root planing significantly reduced bleeding on probing, surface plaque, and probing pocket depth compared to manual toothbrushing, with statistically significant differences at 24 weeks.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-75 with Stage I or II periodontitis.
effective_dosage: Twice daily use of either a powered or manual toothbrush.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Morus alba gel and chlorhexidine gel as adjuncts to Scaling and Root Planing (SRP) in treating stage II periodontitis.
results_summary: Morus alba gel was effective in reducing periodontal pocket depth (PPD) but showed no significant difference compared to chlorhexidine gel in plaque index (PI), gingival index (GI), or microbiological parameters. A statistically significant difference in PPD was observed between the two groups (0.18 mm, p = 0.002).
population_specificity: 180 patients with stage II periodontitis.
effective_dosage: Applied at baseline, 15 days, and 30 days (specific gel amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of scaling and root planing (SRP) with adjunctive antibiotics on periodontal parameters and glycemic control in patients with severe periodontitis and type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Both SRP alone and SRP with antibiotics significantly improved periodontal parameters, with the antibiotic group showing greater improvement in deep pockets (>6 mm). HbA1c levels decreased in both groups, with adjunctive antibiotics associated with a greater reduction, particularly in patients with high baseline HbA1c.
population_specificity: Patients with severe periodontitis and type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: 500 mg amoxicillin and 200 mg metronidazole, three times daily for 7 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of probiotics as an adjunctive therapy to scaling and root planing in managing periodontitis.
results_summary: The systematic review and meta-analysis found that probiotics as an adjunct to scaling and root planing significantly improved periodontal outcomes compared to scaling and root planing alone. The results were statistically significant and clinically relevant.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the early clinical and immunological effects of long-course azithromycin as an adjunct to scaling and root planing in periodontitis patients.
results_summary: Both scaling and root planing (SRP) alone and SRP with adjunct azithromycin (Az) significantly improved clinical outcomes (CAL, PPD, BoP) at 1 month, with no added benefit from Az in these measures. However, Az modulated macrophage polarization (increased CD68+ and CD163+ Mφs density, decreased CD68+/CD163+ ratio) and improved cytokine profiles (reduced IL-1β, IL-6; increased IL-10, TGF-β).
population_specificity: 50 patients with stage I-III, grade A/B periodontitis and 22 periodontally healthy volunteers as a reference group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of curcumin gel combined with Scaling and Root Planing (SRP) on salivary procalcitonin levels in periodontitis treatment.
results_summary: Group III (SRP + curcumin gel) showed greater improvement in plaque index, probing depth, and clinical attachment level compared to Group II (SRP alone). Both groups exhibited a significant decrease in procalcitonin levels after six weeks.
population_specificity: Fifty-four patients (20 male, 34 female) with stage II grade A periodontitis, recruited from Mansoura University's Faculty of Dentistry.
effective_dosage: Curcumin gel applied weekly for four weeks after SRP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and tolerability of scaling and root planing in a patient with gonococcal arthritis and temporomandibular joint pain.
results_summary: The patient tolerated the scaling and root planing procedure well when completed by quadrant, with no reported adverse effects during the intervention. The procedure was effective in managing the patient's condition without exacerbating existing symptoms.
population_specificity: A young female patient with gonococcal arthritis and bilateral temporomandibular joint pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined efficacy of injectable platelet-rich fibrin (i-PRF) and scaling and root planing (SRP) in treating periodontitis in type 2 diabetes mellitus subjects.
results_summary: Both i-PRF + SRP and saline + SRP showed significant improvements in clinical parameters (PPD, CAL, etc.) at 3 and 6 months, with no significant differences between the two treatments. The adjunctive use of i-PRF did not provide additional benefits over saline.
population_specificity: Stage III, grade C periodontitis subjects with type 2 diabetes mellitus (HbA1c > 7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of chlorhexidine (as chips or gel) versus other local antimicrobials when used alongside scaling and root planing in treating periodontitis.
results_summary: Chlorhexidine chips showed better effectiveness on the gingival index after three months, while other antimicrobials outperformed chlorhexidine chips in reducing probing depth at one and three months and were more effective than chlorhexidine gel on plaque index after one month.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontitis, particularly those with probing depths ≥ 5 mm.
study_duration: Outcomes measured at one and three months.

study_goal: To evaluate the clinical efficacy of 940 nm diode laser and propolis gel as adjuncts to Scaling and Root Planing (SRP) in treating Chronic Periodontitis (CP).
results_summary: All groups showed significant reductions in periodontal indices, with adjunctive diode laser and propolis gel demonstrating superior reductions in gingival inflammation, probing depth, and clinical attachment levels compared to SRP alone.
population_specificity: 30 patients with Chronic Periodontitis and probing depth ≥5 mm.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of scaling and root planing (SRP) on salivary IL-6 levels and clinical parameters in chronic periodontitis patients with and without type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: SRP significantly reduced IL-6 levels and improved clinical parameters (gingival index, plaque index, bleeding index, probing depth, and relative attachment level) in both groups, with greater improvements in non-diabetic patients. The study also indicated SRP's role in glycemic control for T2DM patients with chronic periodontitis.
population_specificity: 50 chronic periodontitis patients with well-controlled T2DM (Group I) and 50 chronic periodontitis patients without T2DM (Group II).
study_duration: 30 days (measurements taken at 7, 14, and 30 days post-intervention)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether scaling and root planing, with or without systemic doxycycline, affects blood sugar regulation in type 2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: The study found that scaling and root planing combined with doxycycline significantly reduced glycated hemoglobin levels and improved periodontal health compared to scaling and root planing alone. No significant improvements were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: 60 patients with type 2 diabetes (non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare salivary sCD44 levels in chronic periodontitis patients before and after scaling and root planing (SRP) and assess its potential as a biomarker.
results_summary: Salivary sCD44 levels were significantly higher in chronic periodontitis patients compared to healthy individuals and drastically decreased one month after SRP (p < 0.0001). The study suggests sCD44 could serve as a biomarker for chronic periodontitis.
population_specificity: Half healthy individuals, half chronic periodontitis patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of scaling and root planing alone versus scaling and root planing combined with simvastatin gel or tetracycline fibers in treating periodontitis.
results_summary: After six months, simvastatin gel showed greater improvement in gingival index and bleeding, while tetracycline fibers were more effective in reducing probing depth compared to scaling and root planing alone.
population_specificity: 60 periodontal disease sites (divided into three groups of 20 sites each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the proportion of different patient engagement approaches used by dental hygienists during scaling and root planing and how these approaches varied across task components, hygienist experience, and patient compliance.
results_summary: Paternalism and informed consent were more common than shared decision-making and disengagement by a 4:1 ratio. High patient disengagement (20% no-show rate) suggested patients might prefer more shared decision-making.
population_specificity: Graduates and students from a baccalaureate dental hygiene program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the differential effects of progesterone on periodontitis in perimenopausal women who did or did not undergo Scaling and Root Planing (SRP).
results_summary: SRP significantly improved periodontal health markers (PPD, CAL, SBI, BOP) and reduced inflammatory factors in GCF. Progesterone worsened periodontal inflammation without SRP but had anti-inflammatory effects when combined with SRP, though these effects dissipated after withdrawal.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal women with mild-to-moderate periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical and microbiological efficiency of scaling and root planing (SRP) alone versus laser-assisted new attachment procedure (LANAP) in managing periodontally affected teeth.
results_summary: Both SRP and LANAP were effective in treating chronic periodontal disease, but LANAP showed greater reductions in pocket depth, bleeding on probing, and dental plaque, along with a significant decrease in Porphyromonas gingivalis levels.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic periodontal disease.
